newsitem.title: USA: Chrysler CEO sees replacement of Toledo plant.
newsitem.headline: Chrysler CEO sees replacement of Toledo plant.

text.p: Chrysler Corp chairman Robert Eaton said Monday that the automaker will eventually replace its Toledo, Ohio, Jeep assembly plant, but added that a new facility may not be built in Toledo.
Eaton, speaking to reporters at a dinner Monday night, said the plant could be built as much as 50 miles away from Toledo and still use the same workforce.
"At some point in time, we will replace that plant, not necessarily in Toledo," Eaton said. "It's a competitive world out there."
He declined to offer a timetable for replacement of the plant or say whether Chrysler would seek incentives in deciding its location.

The Toledo facility, much of which was first built in 1910 by the Willys-Overland Co., is currently the oldest operating auto plant in the United States. Chrysler acquired the factory, which builds Jeep Cherokee and Wrangler sport/utility vehicles, in 1987 when it bought American Motors Corp.
The plant employs about 5,575 people and builds 777 Cherokees and 398 Wranglers per day, according to information available on Chrysler's Internet website.
But even without replacing Toledo, Eaton said he believes Chrysler can add up to 1 million units worth of new annual assembly capacity in its present facilities.

He said Chrysler can now build about 3 million units a year and can bring that to roughly 4 million without building a new assembly plant. Instead, Chrysler can increase assembly line rates, add more production shifts and boost the availability of key components, such as engines and transmissions, he said.

Earlier Monday, Chrysler disclosed that it plans to boost its truck production capability by about 190,000 units in 1997 over 1996 levels, which include the production of a new Dodge sport/utility vehicle in Newark, Del.

Eaton said Chrysler is investing about $500 million into the Newark assembly plant for the new vehicle. The investment will pay for a new body shop and a new paint shop that uses a low-emission water-borne painting process, he said.
